candidate: The US Chamber of Commerce has filed a lawsuit against the Trump administration over a new $100,000 (£74,000) fee on H-1B visas for skilled foreign workers. The Chamber, whose Chief Policy Officer Neil Bradley said the charge “will make it cost-prohibitive” for employers, argues the fee—instituted by an executive order last month for new H-1B requests and paired with a “gold card” fast-track option with fees starting at about £1m—will harm hiring in the US tech sector; the White House called the step lawful and necessary. The court challenge will test the administration's authority to impose the levy and could shape how major firms and startups recruit overseas talent.

Paramjit Singh, a 48-year-old US green card holder, has been held in a US immigration detention centre for more than two months after being detained at Chicago O'Hare International Airport. Singh, an Indian passport holder who has lived in the US since 1994 and lives in Indiana with his wife and two US-citizen children whose family owns gas stations, was detained on 30 July while returning from India and faces deportation after US Immigration and Customs Enforcement cited two-decade-old cases. His family and lawyer Louis Angeles say there are no active cases, that Singh — who has a brain tumour and a heart condition — is not receiving adequate treatment and is only getting check-ups, and they are seeking his release or proper medical care while his case remains unresolved.

More than two dozen states, co-led by New York, California and Massachusetts, sued the Trump administration on Tuesday over its decision to suspend food stamps during the government shutdown. The lawsuit asks a federal judge to order the US Department of Agriculture to tap emergency reserves to distribute benefits to nearly 42 million people who rely on SNAP after the USDA said no benefits would be issued on Nov. 1. Democratic attorneys general and three governors say the government is legally required to maintain benefits and have asked for a ruling by Friday. SNAP serves roughly one in eight low-income Americans at about 8 billion per month while the USDA contingency fund is estimated at about 6 billion, and the program's potential expiration has become a major point in the shutdown standoff.

Tiphaine Auzière, daughter of Brigitte Macron, told a Paris court that sexist cyber-bullying has harmed her mother's health and living conditions. Auzière, 41 and the step-daughter of French President Emmanuel Macron, testified on the second and final day of the trial of 10 people accused of spreading unsubstantiated claims about Brigitte Macron's gender and sexuality, saying the 72-year-old has long been the target of conspiracy theories alleging she is transgender. She said her mother's life 'deteriorated' since the attacks, that abuses were reported to her daily, and that Brigitte Macron has had to be careful about outfit choices and posture because her image is used to fuel the rumours.

Donald Trump has filed an appeal to overturn his May 2024 criminal conviction in the New York hush-money payment case, arguing he is shielded by presidential immunity. A unanimous jury convicted Trump on 34 felony counts of falsifying business records after prosecutors said he instructed his lawyer Michael Cohen to pay Stormy Daniels $130,000 before the 2016 election and then reimbursed Cohen through fraudulent entries; in December a judge, citing Trump's imminent return to the White House, imposed an unconditional discharge. The spring 2024 trial unfolded during Trump's re-election campaign, with prosecutors saying the disguised payments amounted to election interference. The Manhattan District Attorney's office has not immediately commented on the latest filing.

U.S. Transportation Secretary Sean Duffy warned on Sunday he will pull millions in federal highway funds from California after accusing the state of illegally issuing commercial driver's licenses to non-citizens and saying Governor Gavin Newsom has refused to comply with Department of Transportation rules. Duffy told Fox News he was “about to pull $160m” and said the department could also strip California's authority to issue CDLs; the Transportation Department tightened rules after three fatal crashes blamed on immigrant truck drivers, announcing emergency regulations on Sept. 26 that took effect Sept. 29, limiting CDLs for non-citizens to three visa classes and requiring federal immigration checks. California DMV spokesperson Eva Spiegel said the state is in compliance and called any withholding of funds illegitimate; if unresolved, Duffy's threat could lead to federal fund cuts or revocation of CDL-issuing authority.

Argentina's President Javier Milei led his La Libertad Avanza party to a landslide in Sunday's midterm elections, winning nearly 41% of the vote. The party won 13 of 24 Senate seats and 64 of 127 contested lower-house seats, up from seven and 37 respectively, easing Milei's path to slash state spending and deregulate the economy. Former US president Donald Trump publicly congratulated Milei and tied a potential $40bn US lifeline to his political momentum, a move critics described as foreign interference. Opposition lawmakers had overturned his vetoes on university and disability funding before the vote, and hundreds of supporters cheered outside a Buenos Aires hotel as results came in.

Hurricane Melissa made landfall in Jamaica on Tuesday as a Category 5 storm, the U.S. National Hurricane Center said in its latest advisory. Seven deaths have been attributed to Melissa across the Caribbean before landfall — three in Jamaica, three in Haiti and one in the Dominican Republic — and more than 240,000 people in Jamaica were without power while roughly a quarter of the country's telecommunications network was offline. Authorities and emergency crews are expected to assess damage and work to restore power and communications in the coming days, and the National Hurricane Center will continue to monitor the storm and issue updates.

Alassane Ouattara has been declared the winner of Ivory Coast's presidential election by a landslide. Provisional results announced by the Independent Electoral Commission on Monday evening show the 83-year-old won a fourth term with 89.77% of the vote, about 3.75 million votes, while runner-up Jean-Louis Billon garnered roughly 3%; Ouattara faced four lesser-known candidates after opposition heavyweights Laurent Gbagbo and Tidjane Thiam were barred from contesting. Barring any surprise from the Constitutional Council during the stipulated five-day challenge period, Ouattara, who has been in office since 2011, is set to lead the world's largest cocoa producer until 2030, a tenure marked by strong growth and infrastructure projects but also accusations of cronyism and repression of opposition.

Hurricane Melissa has slammed into Cuba after sweeping through Jamaica as a catastrophic Category 5 storm, the strongest to hit Jamaica since record-keeping began in 1851. The slow-moving hurricane lashed Jamaica with intense winds and heavy rain that caused extensive damage, with reported winds that escalated from 70 mph to 140 mph (225 km/h) in a single day—one of the fastest intensifications on record in the Atlantic—and has since weakened to Category 3 as it lingers over Cuba. Satellite footage captured the storm's eyewall passing over Jamaica, US Air Force aircraft have flown reconnaissance missions through the system, and forecasters say Melissa could still unleash significant destruction as it moves toward the Bahamas.

Reports say the paramilitary Rapid Support Forces (RSF) carried out ethnically motivated mass killings and other atrocities in El Fasher, in Sudan's western Darfur region, after seizing control of the city over the weekend. Local activists released unverified video showing a fighter known for executing civilians shooting unarmed people at point-blank range and footage showing dozens of bodies and burnt vehicles, while army-allied Joint Forces on Tuesday accused the RSF of executing more than 2,000 unarmed civilians; Yale University's Humanitarian Research Lab said open-source and satellite evidence was consistent with systematic ethnic cleansing of Fur, Zaghawa and Berti communities, including alleged door-to-door clearance operations. The footage has not been independently verified, and the Yale lab says it will continue monitoring the situation with satellite imagery and open-source intelligence as investigators and observers seek to corroborate allegations and document potential crimes.

Immigration officials have deported Chanthila “Shawn” Souvannarath, 44, to Laos despite a federal court order blocking his removal, his attorneys said. U.S. District Judge Shelly Dick last week ordered U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement to keep Souvannarath in the United States while he pressed what the judge called his “substantial claim of U.S. citizenship”; court filings say he was born in a Thai refugee camp and received lawful permanent residence before his first birthday, and he told his wife on Sunday via WhatsApp that he was in Dongmakkhai, Laos. Souvannarath had been detained at a newly opened ICE facility at the Louisiana state penitentiary at Angola, and the ACLU of Louisiana, which represents him, called the deportation a “stunning violation of a federal court order”; ICE and the Department of Homeland Security did not immediately respond to requests for comment.

Paul Biya has been declared the winner of Cameroon's presidential election, granting him an eighth term that could keep him in office until he is nearly 100. The constitutional council said Biya won 53.66% of the vote while his former ally-turned-challenger Issa Tchiroma Bakary received 35.19%; Biya, 92, has been in power since 1982 and removed presidential term limits in 2008. The announcement comes amid tensions: a ban on public gatherings remains in effect, internet restrictions have been reported in the economic capital Douala, and clashes between security forces and opposition supporters left four people dead in Douala and, according to Tchiroma, two killed outside his home in Garoua. The opposition disputes the result and further protests or legal challenges are expected.

Bill Gates has called for a 'strategic pivot' in the climate fight, urging a shift from trying to limit rising temperatures to focusing on preventing disease and poverty. In a note on his Gates Notes website on Monday, the Microsoft co-founder criticized a 'doomsday view of climate change' and said the COP30 summit in Belém, Brazil, in November should refocus leaders on improving lives; his memo followed a UN warning a day earlier that humanity had missed the 1.5C target, with secretary-general António Guterres warning of 'devastating consequences.' Gates acknowledged climate impacts will hit the poorest hardest but argued they will not cause humanity's demise and said scarce resources should prioritize interventions that reduce poverty and disease, a stance at odds with Guterres' call to recognise failure on limiting warming.

Venezuela's President Nicolás Maduro accused the United States of 'fabricating a new war' after Washington ordered the USS Gerald R. Ford, the world's largest warship, to the Caribbean. The carrier, which can carry up to 90 aircraft, will deploy to the US Southern Command area, and the Pentagon said the additional forces are intended to disrupt narcotics trafficking; the US has also conducted 10 air strikes on vessels in the region. President Donald Trump has accused Maduro of leading a drug-trafficking organisation, which Maduro denies, and many countries do not recognise him after a widely disputed 2024 election; Venezuelans fear the military build-up could be aimed at removing Maduro, while US officials say the deployment is meant to curb drug smuggling.

After serving 43 years for a murder he did not commit, Subramanyam 'Subu' Vedam was exonerated earlier this month but was taken into U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement custody and now faces deportation to India. Vedam was convicted in the 1980 killing of his former roommate, 19-year-old college student Tom Kinser, and has not lived in India since he was a baby; his legal team is challenging the deportation order. His sister Saraswathi Vedam says the family is working to secure his release from an ICE facility where he now shares a room with roughly 60 men, and Vedam has urged them to 'focus on the win' as they await next steps.

Researchers in Pennsylvania have uncovered what they say are some of the earliest written musical notes in western music on a ninth-century vellum manuscript leaf from a Latin sacramentary that had remained in the hands of a private collector and was identified by historian Nathan Raab. The notations—characters and dots above the word “alleluia”—appear on a liturgical Easter text probably created in Germany in the second half of the ninth century, and Raab, president of the Raab Collection, says he spent months researching their origin and significance; earlier Western examples include the Laon Gradual and the St Gall Cantatorium from the late ninth or early tenth centuries. Researchers say the marks indicate pitch inflections as visual aids for singers, and the find will prompt further scholarly study and comparison with other early notation sources.

Texas Attorney General Ken Paxton is suing Johnson & Johnson and Kenvue, the makers of Tylenol, alleging they hid dangers the pain reliever posed to children's brain development. Paxton, a Republican, filed the suit a month after President Donald Trump promoted an unproven link between prenatal acetaminophen use and autism, accusing the companies of prioritizing profits; Kenvue countered that there is no credible evidence tying Tylenol to autism and warned against misinformation. Medical organizations including the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists say acetaminophen is among the few recommended options for pain and fever in pregnancy and that decades of research have not produced reputable evidence linking prenatal use to neurodevelopmental disorders; the lawsuit will now proceed through the courts as the parties contest the science and public messaging.

Hurricane Melissa made landfall in Jamaica as a Category 5 storm and is now heading for Cuba. In Jamaica, Minister Desmond Mckenzie said the southwest parish of St Elizabeth was under water, at least three families were trapped in Black River, more than 530,000 people were without electricity and nearly 15,000 were in storm shelters; Cuba's president warned of a “very difficult night” as the storm, now a Category 4, approached Santiago de Cuba. The US National Hurricane Center said Melissa is expected to remain powerful as it moves across Cuba, the Bahamas and near Bermuda, while emergency services contend with extensive infrastructure damage, flooding and landslides.

US forces killed 14 people in strikes on four alleged drug boats in the eastern Pacific, Defence Secretary Pete Hegseth said. Hegseth said the strikes, carried out on Monday at the direction of President Donald Trump, occurred about 400 miles (643 km) off the Mexican Pacific coast and come amid a wider US campaign against suspected narcotics shipments that has killed at least 57 people. The attacks have drawn regional condemnation and questions about their legality; Mexican President Claudia Sheinbaum said she disagrees and has asked officials to meet the US ambassador, while members of Congress from both parties have raised concerns and tensions have risen with Colombia and Venezuela.
